senses.de: Something that someone says or writes officially or publicly to express an opinion, fact or state of affairs.
senses.ex: The company issued a statement about its future plans.

Tips.title: Official Communication
Tips.description: Used when an individual or organization needs to officially share information or views.
Tips.example: The minister's statement clarified the new policy.

Tips.title: Public Impact
Tips.description: Could affect public opinion or convey an important message to a broader audience.
Tips.example: Her statement on climate change influenced the community.

senses.de: A document that gives an official set of numbers or facts about something.
senses.ex: I get a monthly statement from my bank showing all the transactions.

Tips.title: Regular Updates
Tips.description: Regular documents like bank statements help track finances over a period of time.
Tips.example: My bank statement shows all my expenses for this month.

Tips.title: Proof of Activity
Tips.description: Statements often serve as official records to prove financial activities.
Tips.example: The auditor requested all financial statements for the review.

senses.de: A piece of furniture, jewelry, clothing, etc. that is very bold and noticeable.
senses.ex: Her dress really made a statement at the party.

Tips.title: Conveys Personality
Tips.description: Items that make a statement showcase someone's unique style or personality.
Tips.example: His colorful tie really made a statement.

Tips.title: Attention Grabbing
Tips.description: Intended to be bold and catch people's attention immediately.
Tips.example: The sculpture in the lobby makes a striking statement.

senses.de: A formal write-up in law documents providing facts or claims.
senses.ex: His statement of claim was submitted to the court.

Tips.title: Legal Evidence
Tips.description: Legal statements are often used as evidence or to present facts in court.
Tips.example: Her sworn statement was crucial to the case.

Tips.title: Formal Document
Tips.description: A statement in law is an official document and must be written formally and accurately.
Tips.example: The lawyer prepared a statement of defense.

senses.de: In computing, a command or instruction written in a computer programming language.
senses.ex: In Python, a print statement outputs data to the console.

Tips.title: Coding Instructions
Tips.description: In programming, a statement instructs the computer to perform a specific action.
Tips.example: The if statement checks a condition before executing code.

Tips.title: Building Blocks
Tips.description: Statements are the basic building blocks in writing code for software and apps.
Tips.example: Each statement in the program contributes to its overall function.

Affirm.wordDefinition:
Affirm means to state that something is true or to confirm something that has already been said. It is commonly used in legal or official settings, where someone might need to make a formal declaration that something is true.

Affirm is a more formal term that is typically used when someone needs to make a clear and unequivocal statement about something, often in a legal or official context.

Statement, on the other hand, is a more general term that can be used in a wider range of contexts, and does not necessarily carry the same weight of authority or formality as "affirm."

Announce.wordDefinition:
Announce means to make something known publicly or officially, often for the first time. This can be used in various situations such as announcing a new product, a winner of an award, or an upcoming event.

Announce is generally used when something is first being revealed or introduced, while statement is used when someone is making a declaration or taking a stance on something.

Assertion.wordDefinition:
An assertion is a strong claim that is made with confidence, often without evidence to support it.

An assertion is a confident claim made without evidence, while a statement is a declaration backed by evidence.

A statement is more applicable when presenting factual information, while an assertion is more applicable when making a persuasive argument.

Claim.wordDefinition:
A claim is a statement that someone makes where they say that something is true or has happened.

In summary, claims are used in debates, discussions, or scientific papers, while statements are used in everyday conversations, news reports or commentaries.

Claims must have evidence to back them up, while statements are often a reflection of personal views or experiences.

Declaration.wordDefinition:
A declaration is a formal or official announcement or proclamation, usually made by a government or other authority, such as declaring war or independence.

In simpler terms, a declaration is a big, official announcement, while a statement is a general remark or belief. Declarations are usually made by those in charge of large organizations or governments, while statements can be made by anyone.

Expression.wordDefinition:
An expression is any code that evaluates to a value, while a statement is a piece of code that performs an action.

Examples of expressions are:

In general, expressions are used to calculate values, while statements are used to control the flow of a program or interact with the environment.

However, many statements also contain expressions. For example, an if statement contains an expression that is evaluated to determine which code block to execute.

Proclamation.wordDefinition:
A proclamation is a formal public announcement made by a person in authority, like a government official or a king or queen.

A proclamation is a formal public announcement made by someone in authority, while a statement is a more general term that can refer to any kind of declaration or message.

Proclamations are typically reserved for more significant and official announcements, while statements can be made by anyone about anything.

Pronounce.wordDefinition:
Pronounce is used when speaking words out loud and correctly. For example, you might pronounce a difficult word slowly and carefully so that people can understand you.

Pronounce is about speaking words correctly, while statement is about expressing ideas or opinions through words.
